Award.AwardTitle: E2CDA: Type II: Collaborative Research: Nanophotonic Lithium Niobate platform for next generation energy efficient and ultrahigh bandwidth optical interconnect

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
High performance computing systems and data centers dissipate a large amount of power, much of which is spent on data transmission. Optical technology is well poised to increase the efficiency of data transfer, however it brings along new types of energy losses associated with devices responsible for converting the information from the electrical domain, used for computation, to the optical domain, used for communication. This program will overcome this hurdle and will enable realization of efficient and compact electrical-to-optical converters. The program addresses topics related to optical communications, material science, computer modeling, nanotechnology, and electronics, and therefore represents a unique training ground for students at all levels. To engage a wider audience, the team members will prepare public lectures focused on discussing the science and technology used to realize the communication systems that modern society heavily relies on.

The goal of this project is development of highly integrated, micrometer scale, lithium-niobate electro-optic modulators, that have the potential to enable large communication rates with minimal energy consumption. This will allow for efficient data transfer that could meet demanding requirements of future high performance computing systems. The proposed program will advance the state of the art of optoelectronic devices, will explore new device concepts and system architectures, will develop nanofabrication techniques suitable for realization of integrated modulators, and will develop new communication methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Intellectual Merits: In this program we have developed efficient and fast electro-optic modulators realized in integrated lithium-niobate photonic platform. These devices are of interest for realization of optical links used in data centers and long-haul communication networks. Next, we leveraged our devices, and lithium niobate photonic platform in general, to realize different types of frequency comb sources. Optical frequency combs are broadband coherent light sources and precise spectral rulers. They consist of equally spaced discrete optical frequency components and are essential tools for optical communication, precision metrology, timing and spectroscopy. Wide-spanning combs are most often generated from mode-locked lasers or dispersion-engineered resonators with third order optical nonlinearity. We have demonstrated such frequency comb sources could be also realized in our lithium niobate integrated photonic platform. Furthermore, we have integrated these devices with electro-optic switches and modulators, an important step towards realization of high data rate communication systems. In addition, we have investigated the effect of large optical power propagating in these devices, and have observed effects like supercontinuum generation and even Raman lasing. We have explored an alternative method of comb generation that utilizes electro-optic phase modulation in a resonator. Using this approach, we have realized frequency combs with excellent stability and controllability. A key feature of these combs, which differentiates it from Kerr combs, is that they are intrinsically phase-locked and emit optical pulses. Therefore, no sophisticated tuning and controlling mechanisms are needed as in the case of Kerr combs. This opens immense opportunities for applications in sensing, precision measurements, and telecommunication. One exciting application of our comb sources is in optical simulations. We theoretically proposed and experimentally demonstrated that optical frequency crystal of arbitrary dimensions can be formed by hundreds of coupled spectral modes produced by an on-chip electro-optic frequency comb source. We demonstrate that the generation of classical electro-optic frequency comb can be modeled as a process described by random walks in a tight-binding model, and we have veriﬁed this by measuring the coherent distribution of optical steady states. We believe that our platform is a promising candidate for exploration of topological and quantum photonics in the frequency domain.

 

The Broader Impact: The proposed research program provided excellent opportunities to train students in the fields that include optical communications, nanofabrication, integrated photonics and nonlinear optics. The research outcomes were incorporated in undergraduate and graduate courses that PI is teaching at Harvard. Also, the PI has participated in outreach activities in Boston area middle school. This include demonstrations of the basic concepts of optical communication – transmitting music stream via laser beam. The devices and systems that we have developed are of great interest to different scientific communities, including quantum optics, optoelectronics, and nonlinear optics.
